intro: Mascagnia chlorocarpa var. typica, commonly known as the blue mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its striking blue-gray foliage and clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 feet and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in a fine, silvery pubescence, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
